Introduction

Hypoxemia, hypoxia, anemia, and ischemia are related, yet distinct processes:



  • Hypoxemia:  Low dissolved oxygen (O2) content of arterial blood, commonly defined as an arterial partial pressure of O2 (PaO2) <60 mm Hg.  Example:  parenchymal lung disease.
  • Hypoxia:  Low O2 content at the end-organ and tissue level.  It can be caused by hypoxemia, anemia, or ischemia.  Prolonged hypoxia typically results in tissue necrosis.  Example:  myocardial infarction.
  • Anemia:  Low number of circulating red blood cells (and therefore, hemoglobin content) in arterial blood.  Example:  iron deficiency.
  • Ischemia:  Low perfusion of end-organs and tissues, resulting in decreased O2 and other nutrients (eg, glucose).  Example:  arterial thrombosis.


This article discusses the mechanisms, pathophysiology, and evaluation of hypoxemia.

Normal oxygenation



Normal oxygenation requires 3 elements:



  • Normal inspired O2 (ie, normal PiO2).
  • Normal alveolar ventilation (ie, normal PaCO2).
  • Normal alveolar-capillary exchange (ie, normal A-a gradient).

Normal inspired oxygen (PiO2)



PiO2 (partial pressure of inspired O2) is the O2 available in the atmosphere for breathing.  It is determined by the fraction of inspired O2 (FiO2), the atmospheric pressure (Patm), and the water vapor pressure (PH2O).



Under standard conditions:  PiO2 = FiO2 Ã— (Patm âˆ’ PH2O) = 0.21 Ã— (760 âˆ’ 47) â‰ˆ 150 mm Hg:



  • FiO2 = fraction of inspired O2.  It is the percentage of air molecules that are O2.  Normal FiO2 is 21% everywhere on Earth.
  • Patm = atmospheric pressure.  Normal Patm is 760 mm Hg at sea level and decreases with altitude.
  • PH2O = vapor pressure of water in the atmosphere.  Normal PH2O is 47 mm Hg.

Normal alveolar ventilation (PaCO2)



PaCO2 (partial pressure of arterial carbon dioxide) reflects the effectiveness of ventilation, which removes ("blows off") carbon dioxide (CO2).  It is determined by minute ventilation, the product of respiratory rate (RR) and tidal volume (VT).  Normal minute ventilation is 6-8 L/min because normal RR is 12-16/min and normal VT is 500 mL (= 0.5 L).



PaCO2 is measured directly by arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis.  PaCO2 is in equilibrium with PACO2 (partial pressure of alveolar carbon dioxide) because CO2 diffuses instantly between the pulmonary capillary blood and the alveolar airspace.  Therefore, under normal conditions, PACO2 = PaCO2 = 40 mm Hg.



In the alveolus, each molecule of CO2 displaces 0.8 molecule of O2.  PAO2 (partial pressure of alveolar oxygen) is the O2 content present in the alveolar airspace after dilution by CO2.  Normally, PAO2 = PiO2 âˆ’ PACO2 / 0.8 = 150 â€“ 40 / 0.8 = 100 mm Hg.

Normal alveolar-capillary exchange (A-a gradient)



A-a gradient (alveolar-arterial gradient) is the difference between PAO2 and PaO2.



  • PAO2 is normally 100 mm Hg as previously described.
  • PaO2 is normally 75-100 mm Hg and is measured directly by ABG analysis.


A small A-a gradient is normally present due to physiologic right-to-left shunting (eg, thebesian veins, bronchial circulation).  This expected A-a gradient can be predicted from age:  normal A-a gradient â‰ˆ age / 3 â‰ˆ (age / 4) + 4.  The A-a gradient is widened by conditions that disrupt the uptake of oxygen, such as V/Q mismatch, diffusion limitation, and abnormal right-to-left shunting.

Five mechanisms of hypoxemia



There are 5 mechanisms of hypoxemia:



  • 1. Low PiO2.
  • 2. Alveolar hypoventilation (â†‘ PaCO2).
  • Abnormal (â†‘) A-a gradient.
    • 3. V/Q mismatch.
    • 4. Diffusion limitation.
    • 5. Right-to-left shunt.

Low inspired oxygen (â†“PiO2)



Low PiO2 refers to hypoxemia due to insufficient atmospheric O2 available for breathing.  It occurs in 2 situations:



  • Decreased FiO2 (ie, normobaric hypoxemia):  Normal FiO2 is 21% everywhere on Earth.  It drops if another gas displaces O2 in the inspired air.  For example, a massive nitrogen spill can severely depress FiO2, even though Patm remains the same.  In practice, this is a very rare scenario.
  • Decreased Patm (ie, hypobaric hypoxemia):  Normal Patm is 760 mm Hg at sea level.  Atmospheric pressure is decreased at high altitudes.  For example, Patm is only 250 mm Hg at the top of Mount Everest, even though FiO2 is still 21%.  PaO2 declines with rising elevation (
    figure 1
    ), with hypoxemia generally becoming problematic at >2,500 m (8,000 ft), corresponding to the development of high-altitude illness.


With low PiO2, hypoxemia occurs because the initial O2 content reaching the alveoli is decreased.  However, the A-a gradient is normal because O2 transport across the alveolar membrane is unaffected.

Alveolar hypoventilation (â†‘ PaCO2)



Alveolar hypoventilation (

figure 2
) refers to hypoxemia due to the retention of carbon dioxide.  An increase in PaCO2 (hypercapnia) occurs in 3 situations:



  • Central hypoventilation ("won't breathe"):  Central hypoventilation occurs when neural respiratory drive is diminished.  Etiologies include opioids, alcohol, benzodiazepines, and damage to brainstem respiratory centers (eg, tumor, stroke).  Patients have slow and shallow breathing (â†“ RR Ã— â†“ VT), indicating a lack of drive.
  • Peripheral hypoventilation ("can't breathe"):  Peripheral hypoventilation occurs when respiratory mechanics are impaired, even though neural respiratory drive is intact.  Etiologies include neuromuscular disease (eg, myasthenia gravis), chest wall deformities (eg, severe kyphosis), advanced obstructive lung disease (eg, emphysema), and advanced restrictive lung disease (eg, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis).  Patients have rapid and shallow breathing (â†‘ RR Ã— â†“â†“ VT), and minute ventilation decreases when tachypnea cannot compensate for low VT.
  • High dead space (wasted ventilation):  Dead space refers to the portion of the VT that does not participate in gas exchange.
    • Anatomic dead space is formed where no gas exchange occurs in the conducting airways (eg, trachea, bronchi).  It remains constant but can be increased if additional tubing is added to the respiratory circuit (eg, mechanical ventilation).
    • Alveolar dead space is formed by alveoli that are ventilated but not perfused.  It is normally negligible but can be increased by conditions that block alveolar perfusion (eg, pulmonary embolism).  Minute ventilation is decreased despite rapid and deep breathing (â†‘ RR Ã— â†‘ VT) because most of the VT does not participate in gas exchange.


With alveolar hypoventilation, hypoxemia occurs because O2 is displaced by CO2 retained in the alveoli.  However, A-a gradient is normal because O2 transport across the alveolar membrane is intact.

V/Q mismatch



V/Q mismatch (

figure 3
) refers to hypoxemia due to a regional imbalance of air flow (V) and blood flow (Q) reaching the alveoli.  Normally, both V and Q are highest at lung bases and lowest at the lung apices.  Across the entire lung, this averages to a global V/Q ratio = 1 (
figure 4
).  Defects in either V or Q can cause deviations from this ratio:



  • Low V/Q (
    figure 5
    ):  Alveoli are poorly ventilated but continue to be perfused.  Etiologies include airway and airspace disorders such as lobar pneumonia, asthmatic bronchoconstriction, mucus plugging, and atelectasis.
  • High V/Q (
    figure 6
    ):  Alveoli are poorly perfused but continue to be ventilated.  Etiologies include pulmonary vascular disorders such as segmental pulmonary embolus and pulmonary arterial hypertension.  (These high V/Q areas also contribute to increased alveolar dead space, as previously described.)


With V/Q mismatch, hypoxemia occurs because Q and V are not efficiently localized together, producing an elevated A-a gradient.

Diffusion limitation



Diffusion limitation (

figure 7
) refers to hypoxemia due to factors that impair O2 transfer across the alveolar membrane.  Normally, O2 diffuses quickly and is fully extracted by the time blood has traveled only a third of the pulmonary capillary length.  This explains why exercise, which can increase pulmonary Q, does not result in hypoxemia.  However, 2 major processes can limit diffusion:



  • Destruction of the alveolar membrane (eg, emphysema) decreases the surface area available for O2 uptake.
  • Thickening of the alveolar membrane (eg, interstitial lung disease) increases the diffusion distance for O2.


Unlike V/Q mismatch, which involves regional or focal abnormalities (eg, segmental pulmonary embolus), diffusion limitation involves diffuse abnormalities of the lung parenchyma.



With diffusion limitation, hypoxemia occurs because O2 transit across the alveolar membrane is impaired (ie, elevated A-a gradient).  In many cases, patients can be normoxic at rest but develop hypoxemia with exertion.

Right-to-left shunting



Right-to-left shunting refers to hypoxemia due to the direct mixture of deoxygenated blood with oxygenated blood.  It occurs in 3 scenarios:



  • Intracardiac anatomic shunt:  An intracardiac communication is seen with atrial or ventricular septal defects.  Normally, oxygenated blood flows from the left chambers (higher pressure) to the deoxygenated right chambers (lower pressure).  However, the flow can reverse if the right-sided pressures increase, such as with the development of pulmonary hypertension, known as Eisenmenger syndrome (
    figure 8
    ).
  • Intrapulmonary anatomic shunt:  An intrapulmonary anatomic shunt is seen with pulmonary arteriovenous malformations, which are anomalous connections between the deoxygenated pulmonary arteries and oxygenated pulmonary veins (bypassing the alveolar capillaries).
  • Intrapulmonary shunt effect:  In patients with extensive alveolar edema (eg, severe acute respiratory distress syndrome), the V/Q ratio can be close to 0, such that blood passing through the lungs barely receives oxygen.  This produces a functional right-to-left shunt, even though no direct anatomic connection is present.


With right-to-left shunting, hypoxemia occurs because deoxygenated blood mixes directly with oxygenated blood.  The A-a gradient is elevated.  Hypoxemia is often severe and does not correct with supplemental O2 because a portion of the blood flow never reaches the lungs to be oxygenated.

Evaluation of hypoxemia



ABG analysis can be approached in 2 ways.  A physiologic method, emphasizing stepwise interpretation without clinical context, is presented here.  In contrast, a clinical method, in which ABG is reserved for complex cases of hypoxemia in which clinical data alone are insufficient, is discussed in a separate article.  When reviewing an ABG, it is a good habit to apply a systematic framework even when the condition seems clinically obvious.



Formal stepwise ABG analysis of hypoxia (

figure 9
) involves the 3 steps illustrated below.

Step 1:  Compare PaO2 and SaO2



PaO2 is measured on ABG, and SaO2 (O2 saturation) is measured by pulse oximetry.  They are related by the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve (

figure 10
).  Dyshemoglobinemias can lead to discrepancies between these 2 values.



  • Methemoglobinemia:  Methemoglobin is hemoglobin in which iron is oxidized to the ferric (Fe3+) state, which cannot bind oxygen.  Therefore, the amount of functional hemoglobin available is reduced, leading to decreased SaOâ‚‚.  However, the amount of O2 dissolved in plasma is normal (ie, arterial blood is normoxic), meaning that PaO2 is normal.
  • Carboxyhemoglobinemia:  Carboxyhemoglobin forms when carbon monoxide (rather than oxygen) binds to hemoglobin.  Carboxyhemoglobin absorbs light at a similar wavelength to oxyhemoglobin, causing pulse oximeters to misclassify it.  Therefore, SaO2 (measured by pulse oximetry) reads as normal (or even artificially high), and blood may appear deceptively pink, even though functional oxygen-carrying capacity is reduced and true hypoxemia (eg, PaO2 <60 mm Hg) may be present.


Additional testing for abnormal hemoglobin species (eg, multiwavelength CO-oximetry) may be indicated to explain the PaO2-SaO2 gap.



Severe acidosis or alkalosis can shift the oxygen-hemoglobin curve to the right or left, respectively.  For example, acidosis leads to the SaO2 reading higher than expected for PaO2 because it favors unloading into tissues.

Step 2:  Calculate A-a gradient



The A-a gradient is a 4-step process that follows inspired gas as it moves from the atmosphere into the alveolar capillaries.



  • First, calculate PiO2:

    • When breathing room air at sea level, PiO2 = FiO2 Ã— (Patm âˆ’ PH2O) = 0.21 Ã— (760 âˆ’ 47) â‰ˆ 150 mm Hg.  This value changes at different altitudes or with the use of supplemental oxygen.
  • Second, calculate PAO2:
    • As discussed previously, PAO2 is the alveolar O2 content after dilution by CO2.  Each molecule of CO2 displaces 0.8 molecules of O2.  PaCO2 is taken from the ABG and is normally 40 mm Hg.  Therefore, normal PAO2 = PiO2 Ã— PaCO2 / 0.8 = 150 â€“ 40 / 0.8 = 100 mm Hg.
  • Third, calculate A-a gradient:
    • A-a gradient is the difference between PAO2 (calculated above) and PaO2 (measured from ABG).  For example, a normal PaO2 = 90 mm Hg.  Therefore, normal A-a gradient = 100 âˆ’ 90 = 10 mm Hg.
  • Finally, determine expected A-a gradient for age:
    • The physiologic A-a gradient increases with age.  Expected A-a gradient = (age / 4) + 4 â‰ˆ age / 3.  The calculated A-a gradient in the previous step should be compared to this expected value.  A normal A-a gradient is due to low PiO2 or alveolar hypoventilation.  An elevated A-a gradient is due to V/Q mismatch, diffusion limitation, or right-to-left shunt.

Step 3a:  If A-a gradient is normal



Hypoxemia with normal A-a gradient is due to alveolar hypoventilation (most common) or low PiO2 (usually clinically obvious).



  • Alveolar hypoventilation is indicated by elevated PaCO2 (ie, >45 mm Hg).
  • Low PiO2, such as high altitude, is usually accompanied by low PaCO2 due to hyperventilation.

Step 3b:  If A-a gradient is elevated



Hypoxemia with elevated A-a gradient is due to V/Q mismatch, diffusion limitation, or right-to-left shunting.  These can be differentiated by the response to supplemental oxygen.



  • V/Q mismatch or diffusion limitation:  The hypoxemia responds quickly to supplemental oxygen.  The A-a gradient is wide but remains relatively constant at all levels of supplemental oxygen.  For example:

    • On room air:  PAO2 = 100 and PaO2 = 50, so A-a gradient = 50 mm Hg.
    • On 40% FiO2:  PAO2 = 240 and PaO2 = 190, so A-a gradient = 50 mm Hg still.  (The higher starting PiO2 can "overcome" the A-a gradient to normalize the PaO2.)
  • Right-to-left shunting:  Hypoxemia does not respond to any level of supplemental oxygen.  The A-a gradient is wide and continues to increase at higher levels of supplemental oxygen.  For example:
    • On room air:  PAO2 = 100 and PaO2 = 50, so A-a gradient = 50 mm Hg.
    • On 100% FiO2:  PAO2 = 660 but PaO2 = 50 still.  (Even pure O2 is ineffective because shunted blood bypasses the alveoli entirely.)

Effects of hypoxemia

Tissue responses



Tissue hypoxia is sensed by hypoxia-inducible factor-1 alpha (HIF1É‘)

figure 11
).  HIF1É‘ is a transcription factor that is constitutively expressed by most cells.  In normoxic cytosol, HIF1É‘ is constantly degraded; in contrast, in hypoxic cytosol, it is posttranslationally stabilized.  HIF1É‘ can have adaptive or potentially maladaptive effects, depending on the severity and duration of hypoxia:



  • Erythropoiesis:  HIF1É‘ induces the upregulation of erythropoietin in kidney juxtaglomerular cells and stimulates iron uptake in gut epithelium (
    figure 12
    ).

    • Adaptively, this allows for compensatory polycythemia (generally, hematocrit >50% and hemoglobin >16.5 mg/dL) to boost oxygen-carrying capacity.
    • Maladaptively, extreme polycythemia (eg, generally, hematocrit >60%) can cause a type of hyperviscosity syndrome in which vascular sludging produces neurologic symptoms (eg, headache, confusion), thrombosis, retinal edema, mucosal bleeding (eg, epistaxis), and heart failure.
  • Angiogenesis:  HIF1É‘ induces the upregulation of vascular endothelial growth factor, mainly in the heart and skeletal muscle.
    • Adaptively, this promotes the formation of collateral circulation (eg, to bypass chronic coronary artery stenosis).
    • Maladaptively, disorganized neovascularization (eg, diabetic proliferative retinopathy) results in fragile, hemorrhage-prone vessels.
  • Anaerobic (glycolytic) shift:  HIF1É‘ induces upregulation of glycolytic enzymes (eg, hexokinase), mainly in the heart and brain.
    • Adaptively, this preserves ATP production despite low O2 (eg, hibernating myocardium).
    • Maladaptively, this results in several downstream changes, such as cellular proliferation (eg, Warburg effect in cancer cells, in which glucose is converted to lactate via aerobic glycolysis in the cytosol rather than being fully metabolized in the mitochondria, fueling rapid cell growth).  This shift also results in inflammation (eg, leukocyte activation due to glycolytic products).

Vascular responses



Effects of hypoxia on vascular resistance are not dependent on HIF1É‘.  Instead, vessels respond directly to O2 itself, reactive oxygen species, or related metabolites.



  • Systemic vasodilation:  Hypoxia (eg, exercising skeletal muscle) stimulates the production of anaerobic metabolites such as adenosine, lactate, and nitric oxide that promote vasodilation.  Low O2 tension directly relaxes vascular smooth muscle (eg, O2-sensitive potassium and calcium channels).  These processes increase arterial perfusion to hypoxic tissue.
  • Pulmonary vasoconstriction (
    figure 13
    ):  Hypoxia is sensed by pulmonary arterioles, likely through mitochondrial redox potential, stimulating vasoconstriction.
    • This is adaptive for short-term, regional hypoxia (eg, atelectatic lobe), because the selective vasoconstriction limits perfusion to poorly ventilated alveoli, maintaining V/Q matching.
    • However, it is maladaptive for chronic, global hypoxia (eg, untreated obstructive sleep apnea) because whole-lung vasoconstriction can lead to pulmonary hypertension (eg, cor pulmonale, Group 3)

Ventilatory response



Hypoxemia stimulates peripheral chemoreceptors in the aortic arch and carotid bodies.  These chemoreceptors signal the medullary respiratory center to increase ventilation through deeper breaths and increased RR.  Hyperventilation has a much larger impact on lowering PaCO2 than on raising PaO2 (

figure 14
).



  • Ventilation:  Hyperventilation causes an immediate reduction in PaCO2 (respiratory alkalosis) because CO2 elimination is directly proportional to minute ventilation.
  • Oxygenation:  Hyperventilation increases PaO2 by only a small amount because perfusion to well-ventilated alveoli is already maximized, so further increases in ventilation do not significantly enhance O2 uptake (ie, ceiling effect).  The hemoglobin in these regions is already near full saturation.


In other words, high V/Q areas (ie, hyperventilation) cannot compensate (

figure 15
) for low V/Q units (eg, mismatch).  Breathing faster and harder will blow down CO2 but does not improve oxygenation.

Cell death



Severe or sustained hypoxemia can result in cell death, especially when combined with ischemia (eg, hypotension).  The dual insult of hypoxemia and hypotension is much more likely to cause tissue necrosis than either alone.  Tissue tolerance varies widely:  Kidneys (eg, acute tubular necrosis) can fully recover even after 15 minutes of complete circulatory arrest, whereas hypoxic-ischemic brain injury may be irreversible after just 3-5 minutes.

Summary



Hypoxemia (PaO2 <60 mm Hg) can be caused by 5 mechanisms:  low inspired oxygen (eg, high altitude), alveolar hypoventilation (eg, opioid-induced respiratory depression), ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch (eg, lobar pneumonia), diffusion limitation (eg, interstitial lung disease), and right-to-left shunting (eg, atrial septal defect).  The alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient assesses oxygen exchange across the alveolar capillary membrane and helps to identify the underlying mechanism.  Hypoxemia with a normal A-a gradient is due to low inspired oxygen or alveolar hypoventilation (ie, high PaCO2).  Hypoxemia with an elevated A-a gradient is due to V/Q mismatch, diffusion limitation, or right-to-left shunting.  A poor response to 100% supplemental oxygen suggests shunt physiology.
